segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Change the system time security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Change the system time security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Change the system time security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Change the system time security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which users can adjust the time on the device's internal clock.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which users can adjust the time on the device's internal clock.

segment.source: This right allows the computer user to change the date and time associated with records in the event logs, database transactions, and the file system.
segment.target: This right allows the computer user to change the date and time associated with records in the event logs, database transactions, and the file system.

segment.source: This right is also required by the process that performs time synchronization.
segment.target: This right is also required by the process that performs time synchronization.

segment.source: This setting does not impact the user’s ability to change the time zone or other display characteristics of the system time.
segment.target: This setting does not impact the user’s ability to change the time zone or other display characteristics of the system time.

segment.source: For info about assigning the right to change the time zone, see Change the time zone.
segment.target: For info about assigning the right to change the time zone, see Change the time zone.

segment.source: Restrict the Change the system time user right to users with a legitimate need to change the system time.
segment.target: Restrict the Change the system time user right to users with a legitimate need to change the system time.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default, members of the Administrators and Local Service groups have this right on workstations and servers.
segment.target: By default, members of the Administrators and Local Service groups have this right on workstations and servers.

segment.source: Members of the Administrators, Server Operators, and Local Service groups have this right on domain controllers.
segment.target: Members of the Administrators, Server Operators, and Local Service groups have this right on domain controllers.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features, tools and guidance to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features, tools and guidance to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Users who can change the time on a computer could cause several problems.
segment.target: Users who can change the time on a computer could cause several problems.

segment.source: Time stamps on event log entries could be made inaccurate
segment.target: Time stamps on event log entries could be made inaccurate

segment.source: Time stamps on files and folders that are created or modified could be incorrect
segment.target: Time stamps on files and folders that are created or modified could be incorrect

segment.source: Computers that belong to a domain might not be able to authenticate themselves
segment.target: Computers that belong to a domain might not be able to authenticate themselves

segment.source: Users who try to log on to the domain from devices with inaccurate time might not be able to authenticate.
segment.target: Users who try to log on to the domain from devices with inaccurate time might not be able to authenticate.

segment.source: Also, because the Kerberos authentication protocol requires that the requester and authenticator have their clocks synchronized within an administrator-defined skew period, an attacker who changes a device's time may cause that computer to be unable to obtain or grant Kerberos protocol tickets.
segment.target: Also, because the Kerberos authentication protocol requires that the requester and authenticator have their clocks synchronized within an administrator-defined skew period, an attacker who changes a device's time may cause that computer to be unable to obtain or grant Kerberos protocol tickets.

segment.source: The risk from these types of events is mitigated on most domain controllers, member servers, and end-user computers because the Windows Time Service automatically synchronizes time with domain controllers in the following ways:
segment.target: The risk from these types of events is mitigated on most domain controllers, member servers, and end-user computers because the Windows Time Service automatically synchronizes time with domain controllers in the following ways:

segment.source: All desktop client devices and member servers use the authenticating domain controller as their inbound time partner.
segment.target: All desktop client devices and member servers use the authenticating domain controller as their inbound time partner.

segment.source: All domain controllers in a domain nominate the primary domain controller (PDC) emulator operations master as their inbound time partner.
segment.target: All domain controllers in a domain nominate the primary domain controller (PDC) emulator operations master as their inbound time partner.

segment.source: All PDC emulator operations masters follow the hierarchy of domains in the selection of their inbound time partner.
segment.target: All PDC emulator operations masters follow the hierarchy of domains in the selection of their inbound time partner.

segment.source: The PDC emulator operations master at the root of the domain is authoritative for the organization.
segment.target: The PDC emulator operations master at the root of the domain is authoritative for the organization.

segment.source: Therefore, we recommend that you configure this computer to synchronize with a reliable external time server.
segment.target: Therefore, we recommend that you configure this computer to synchronize with a reliable external time server.

segment.source: This vulnerability becomes much more serious if an attacker is able to change the system time and then stop the Windows Time Service or reconfigure it to synchronize with a time server that is not accurate.
segment.target: This vulnerability becomes much more serious if an attacker is able to change the system time and then stop the Windows Time Service or reconfigure it to synchronize with a time server that is not accurate.

segment.source: Restrict the Change the system time user right to users with a legitimate need to change the system time, such as members of the IT team.
segment.target: Restrict the Change the system time user right to users with a legitimate need to change the system time, such as members of the IT team.

segment.source: There should be no impact because time synchronization for most organizations should be fully automated for all computers that belong to the domain.
segment.target: There should be no impact because time synchronization for most organizations should be fully automated for all computers that belong to the domain.

segment.source: Computers that do not belong to the domain should be configured to synchronize with an external source, such as a web service.
segment.target: Computers that do not belong to the domain should be configured to synchronize with an external source, such as a web service.
